PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Rebecca Bennett
Address: Margaret, Sask.
Birthplace: __________________

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1902
Where did you set up housekeeping? Grassley Lake Ranch
Where had you been living before that? Wascana, Alta.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Three regularly, others?
How far was it to your nearest store? Matson, Alta., about 60 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, canned milk, dried fruit, baking soda, syrup, corn starch, rice, tapioca, corn meal, oat meal etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ____________________________
In what quantities did you buy it? 300 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? Very little
Whole wheat flour? ____________________________
Was flour milled locally? Yes, near ranch
How far away? What year? ____________________________
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ____________________________
What other grain products did you use? ____________________________
Cornmeal? ____________________________ Whole Wheat? ____________________________ Farina? ____________________________
Other? ____________________________
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ____________________________
How did you grind it? Office Grinder

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - for 3 man 24 woman 20
oat meal & canned milk & sugar,
toast & bacon, dried fruit or jam,
corn potatoes, ham or corned beef, beans,
biscuit or bread butter, raisin or dried apple pie,
supper, sometimes soup (milk & onion), cold meat, fried potatoes,
bread & biscuit, jams or dried fruit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the month, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

1903, roast beef & gravy, man 25
market potato, 1 " 26
turkey, 1 " 21
mustard pickle bought in taps, hot,
steamed custard pudding, vanilla sauce.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had enough to eat but were often without butter or milk, sometimes meat.

   1 cup coffee, 1 glass milk

Dinner: 1 roast beef, 1 boiled potato, 1 vegetable,
   1 cup soup, 1 glass water

Supper: 1 cup tea, 1 piece cake, 1 glass milk

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the earliest days there was no thought given to vitamins or balanced diet, and the value of milk in the diet was not recognized.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

For our storage we made an outside cellar, a deep square hole, with steps cut in the earth & cover, ties (railroad) over top and covered deeply with earth, and a frame was set in with a door. Was very good for to keep vegetables, canned foods, milk & butter also for cool water.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the
   early days as compared with today.

   In the early days, there was no flour,
   and we had to make our own bread.

21. What did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead
   of home-prepared foods?

   We began to rely on canned goods and frozen foods.
